Legal_Issue: Did the citizenship judge err by failing to apply the qualitative test for residency when assessing Mr. Dedaj's application?
Application_Facts: Mr. Dedaj met the physical presence requirement of 1,095 days in Canada but had post-application ties to the U.S.
Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed; case remanded for reconsideration
Remedy_Requested: Reassessment of citizenship application using both quantitative and qualitative residency tests
Court_Ruling: The judge erred in law by not applying the qualitative test for residency as established in the Koo case
Defendant_Behavior: Citizenship judge focused on post-application U.S. ties without considering qualitative residency factors
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to apply the qualitative test for residency despite meeting physical presence requirements
Legal_Standard: Residency must be assessed using both physical presence (1,095 days) and qualitative factors to determine if residency was established and maintained
Assessment_Factor: Ties to Canada, duration and nature of absences, intention to reside in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from dismissal of citizenship application
Review_Standard: Correctness, due to legal error in application of residency test
Evidence_Used: Evidence of physical presence in Canada, evidence of post-application ties to the U.S.
Application_Basis: Meeting 1,095-day physical presence requirement and maintaining factual residence in Canada
Evidence_Assessed: Duration of stay in Canada, connections to the U.S. after application
Relief_Sought: Granting of citizenship following proper assessment of residency
Governing_Rule: Qualitative test for residency as per Koo case must be applied alongside physical presence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider qualitative evidence of residency despite sufficient physical presence
Outcome: Appeal allowed; application remanded for reassessment
Harm_Assessment: Unfair denial of citizenship due to incorrect legal interpretation
Cause_Description: Mr. Dedaj's citizenship application was dismissed due to perceived insufficient physical presence, despite meeting the 1,095-day requirement
Evidence_Handling: Post-application conduct given undue weight; pre- and during-application residency factors inadequately assessed
Legal_Provision_Violated: Failure to comply with the full residency assessment under the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Issues: Overemphasis on post-application U.S. ties without evaluating totality of residency indicators
Residency_Compliance: Met quantitative requirement (1,095 days); qualitative compliance requires further assessment
Evidence_Assessment: Incomplete assessment of residency based on selective consideration of ties
Decision_Rationale: Legal error occurred by omitting the qualitative test for residency; reassessment required
Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient consideration of qualitative factors from Koo case
Legal_Standard_Applied: Two-part test: physical presence + qualitative assessment of residency
